Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of a Holistic Approach to Atherosclerosis Management

Trial_Design.evidence: randomly assigned to either a multidisciplinary team-led holistic care model or standard care. Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Participants.evidence: Participants were adults with risk factors for atherosclerosis, recruited from multiple healthcare centers.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received comprehensive vascular assessments and multidisciplinary care, while the control group received standard care.

Objective.evidence: To assess the effectiveness of a holistic approach in improving vascular health outcomes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the reduction in cardiovascular events over a 12-month period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, with 100 in each group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a significant reduction in cardiovascular events (mean difference = 5.2 events, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild and occurred in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group.

Funding.evidence: This trial was funded by the National Institutes of Health.
